questions.text: A man is on trial for assault. The prosecution presents a witness who testifies under oath that she saw the accused strike the victim with a metal rod during an argument. There is no video footage, no fingerprints on the weapon, and no DNA evidence linking the accused to the crime scene. However, the witness insists she saw the incident clearly from across the street. What type of evidence does the witness’s testimony constitute?

choices.text: City Hospital is liable because Dr. Smith uses its name.
City Hospital is liable due to vicarious liability for Dr. Smith’s negligence.
City Hospital is not liable because Dr. Smith acted outside the scope of hospital employment.
City Hospital is not liable because Dr. Smith had malpractice insurance.

questions.text: Dr. Smith, a licensed surgeon, works at City Hospital as an independent contractor. During a private procedure in his own clinic, which does not belong to the hospital’s facilities, he negligently injures a patient. The patient sues both Dr. Smith and City Hospital. Which statement is correct regarding the hospital’s liability?
questions.solution: Ans. C) City Hospital is not liable because Dr. Smith acted outside the scope of hospital employment.

choices.text: Accused will be responsible since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.
Accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
Accused will be responsible due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.
The accused will not be responsible only if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the criminal responsibility of mentally ill?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence

choices.text: The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death.
The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.
The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology expert who testifies that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents.  The defence argues that the expert’s testimony should be inadmissible as toxicology expert neither  examined the victim while he was alive, nor he conducted the autopsy himself. Which of the below is true?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

choices.text: Brain fingerprinting measures heart rate variability.
Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses.
Brain fingerprinting determines truthfulness through galvanic skin response.

questions.text: A 35-year-old intelligence officer is undergoing screening to ensure loyalty and integrity before receiving a high-security clearance. Investigators decide to use a method based on measuring brain recognition signals, which is unaffected by emotional reactions. Which of the following best differentiates brain fingerprinting from polygraph testing?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses

questions.text: A forensic science student is examining a case study where a body exhibited an unusual glow during the postmortem examination. The instructor explains that this phenomenon, known as postmortem luminescence, can be caused by specific types of bacteria. Which bacteria are known to produce Postmortem Luminescence?

choices.text: Dribbling of saliva occurs in antemortem hanging and on same side of ligature knot. It does not occur in ligature strangulation
Dribbling of saliva occurs in antemortem hanging and opposite to side of ligature knot. It does not occur in ligature strangulation
Dribbling of saliva occurs in both antemortem hanging and ligature strangulation, opposite to side of ligature knot.
Dribbling of saliva occurs in both antemortem hanging and ligature strangulation, on same side of ligature knot.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to dribbling of saliva in hanging?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Dribbling of saliva occurs in antemortem hanging and opposite to side of ligature knot. It does not occur in ligature strangulation

choices.text: Direct trauma to the lungs from water entry
Rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure during forced expirations
Inhalation of foreign particles leading to lung irritation
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to water aspiration

questions.text: What is the primary cause of Paltauf's haemorrhages in drowning?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Rupture of alveolar walls due to increased pressure during forced expirations

choices.text: In hot environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down.
In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down
In cold environments, rigor mortis persist for more time due to faster decomposition
In hot environments, rigor mortis persist for more time due to faster decomposition

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the effect of environmental temperature on rigor mortis is most accurate?
questions.solution: Ans. B) In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down

choices.text: Severe maternal hypertension leading to intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Brain ischemia leading to intrauterine death
Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death, leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones
A genetic anomaly causing cranial bone malformation

questions.text: The Spalding sign, characterized by the overlapping of cranial bones in a fetus after intrauterine death, is primarily caused by:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones.

choices.text: Heat stiffening due to ATP depletion
Protein coagulation due to heat stroke
Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.text: True about the below image:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. Doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. It is suggestive of?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Repeated anal sex with child

choices.text: Presence of smegma, indicating no sexual activity within the last 24 hours.
Presence of glycogen in vaginal cells, indicating possible sexual activity within the last 4 days.
Reaction to urinary residue, indicating recent urination.
Absence of cleaning, indicating poor personal hygiene.

questions.text: A forensic expert conducts a Lugol's iodine test on an accused's glans penis during an examination 48 hours after an alleged sexual assault. The filter paper turns brownish. What does this color change indicate, and why does this reaction occur?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Presence of glycogen in vaginal cells, indicating possible sexual activity within the last 4 days.

choices.text: Toluidine dye should be used to detect recent microinjuries on genitalia before taking the swab for sperm detection
History should not be taken from the victim if her age < 12 years
Radiological confirmation of age of victim should be done in every case of rape victim examination
Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to examination of a female victim of sexual assault?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after consuming a large amount of locally brewed alcohol. He presents with mild confusion, dizziness, and slight unsteadiness while walking. Laboratory results show a normal anion gap, normal pH, normal calcium and normal serum bicarbonate levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

Forced diuresis with acidification or alkalinization of urine is a common method for the elimination of certain poisons or drugs from the body. The elimination of which of the following drugs is commonly enhanced by alkaline diuresis?

choices.text: Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin
Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by nitric acid
Deep tissue liquefactive necrosis by some alkali

questions.text: In a case involving suspected chemical exposure, an autopsy reveals extensive skin discoloration as seen in the image. What can be the likely mechanism?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Reaction of nitric acid with amino acids in the skin

choices.text: Accumulation of oxygenated hemoglobin as cells are not able to use oxygen
Increased carboxyhemoglobin due to carbon monoxide production
Cyanide binding to hemoglobin, enhancing oxygen affinity
Formation of a cyanide-cytochrome c oxidase complex with a cherry red color

questions.text: In cyanide poisoning, the characteristic cherry red discoloration of the skin is best explained by:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Accumulation of oxygenated hemoglobin as cells are not able to use oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following substances of abuse has effects that are most similar to those of cocaine?

Identify which of the following statements are true regarding the materials required for forensic analysis of specific poisons:

 

  1. Vitreous humor is commonly examined for alcohol poisoning.
  2. The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning.
  3. Brain tissue is essential for detecting organophosphate poisoning.
  4. Fatty tissue is primarily used for examining pesticides and insecticides.
questions.solution: Ans. B) Only 1, 3, and 4 are true

choices.text: Excessive scratching and rubbing in psoriatic plaques

questions.text: What is a Woronoff ring associated with, in the context of psoriasis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Gradual resolution of psoriasis

questions.text: An elderly man develops itchy plaques that rapidly evolve into tense bullae on his lower limbs. The blisters are firm and do not rupture easily. Tzanck smear from the blister base shows no evidence of acantholytic cells. A skin biopsy is planned to identify the underlying process. Which histological feature is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Basement membrane zone destruction

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with joint stiffness, fatigue, low-grade fever, and a photosensitive facial rash. She reports generalized body aches and difficulty performing daily tasks due to pain and stiffness in her hands and knees. Routine blood work reveals mild anemia. Urinalysis is unremarkable. A provisional diagnosis of SLE was made. Based on prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) manifestations during the disease course, which of the following is the most likely presenting feature in this patient?

A 35-year-old individual presents with asymptomatic streak-like pigmentation over the anterior neck and upper chest. The discoloration developed shortly after the application of a scented product followed by sun exposure. There is no associated itching or discomfort, but the pigmentation is concerning. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?

A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for gradual darkening and thickening of the skin on the back of her neck over several months. She denies pruritus or pain. On examination, the skin is hyperpigmented, velvety, and slightly raised in texture. Her BMI is 34 kg/m², and laboratory evaluation reveals elevated fasting insulin levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition responsible for her skin findings?

A 5-month-old infant is brought to the dermatology OPD with intense itching, especially at night. On examination, there are multiple excoriated papules and burrows seen over the palms, soles, and trunk. A clinical diagnosis of scabies is made. The paediatrician plans to initiate therapy. Which of the following drugs are appropriate and safe for use in infants with scabies?

 

  1. Permethrin 5% cream
  2. Benzyl benzoate 25% lotion
  3. Crotamiton 10% cream
  4. Ivermectin

Which of the following statements is true about thalidomide?

 

  1. Its anti-inflammatory action is due to inhibition of TNF-α production
  2. Used in management of refractory relapsing multiple myeloma
  3. Used in management of Type 1 Lepra reaction
  4. It is a teratogenic drug to fetus
Erythematous lesions with collarette scales on the trunk are characteristic of which of the following diseases?

A 24-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks gestation presents with multiple exophytic verrucous lesions on the vulva and perineum. She denies pain or discharge. On examination, the lesions are consistent with genital warts. Based on safety and efficacy during pregnancy, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?

choices.text: Multinucleated Giant Cells are seen in Varicella-Zoster Infections.
Acantholytic Cells are seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris
It is the most Accurate Test for Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Tzanck smear findings except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) It is the most Accurate Test for Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: All of the following is / are the location of stem cells in the skin except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Base of Apocrine Glands

questions.text: A young woman presents with a single, painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Based on these features, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man with a long-standing history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with a gradually enlarging lesion on the face. The lesion is described as painless, pearly with rolled borders and has developed central ulceration over the past several weeks. On physical examination, the lesion appears locally invasive, but there is no regional lymphadenopathy. Based on this clinical picture, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A young male presents with painful grouped vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by superficial erosion. A Tzanck smear from the base of a vesicle is as seen in the image provided. According to the syndromic management guidelines followed under NACO, which of the following treatment kits should be administered?

A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive hair loss over the scalp. On examination, there is significant thinning and receding of the frontal hairline, along with bitemporal recession and vertex involvement. The hair loss follows a patterned distribution, and no scarring or scaling is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Spongiosis is seen in Acute Eczema
Acanthosis is the thickening of Stratum Spinosum
Acantholysis is seen in Bullous Pemphigoid

questions.text: Identify the false statement among the following:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Acantholysis is seen in Bullous Pemphigoid

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a hypopigmented skin lesion and a satellite lesion nearby. On examination, there is thickening of a peripheral nerve. Two MDT blister packs are provided for reference. According to the revised WHO/NLEP guidelines (April 1, 2025), which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
Match the following dermatological terms with their correct definitions:

A 19-year-old woman presents for follow-up during treatment for severe nodulocystic acne. She denies fever, rash, or any changes in her medications. Which of the following is the most common adverse effect associated with her current therapy?
Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to the morpholine class of antifungal agents?

choices.text: It causes severe effects on kidney
It is structural analogue of isoflurane
It has very high blood gas partition coefficients
It is metabolically unstable in the body

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient is scheduled for a routine orthopedic surgery under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist opts to use desflurane as the primary inhaled anesthetic agent. While discussing its properties with a trainee, the anesthesiologist reviews several characteristics of desflurane. Which one of the following statements regarding desflurane is correct?
questions.solution: Ans. B) It is a structural analogue of isoflurane

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is scheduled for a brief outpatient endoscopic procedure under monitored anesthesia care in a day-care setting. She requires adequate intraoperative analgesia but must recover quickly after the procedure to be discharged home the same day. The anesthesiologist must choose an opioid that provides effective pain control while allowing rapid postoperative recovery with minimal residual sedation. Which opioid is most suitable for intraoperative analgesia in this scenario?

A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation is scheduled for a total knee arthroplasty. He is currently managed on warfarin therapy, which has been held for the past 5 days. Preoperative labs show a platelet count of 65,000/mm³, and he reports taking aspirin 75 mg up until two days ago. He does not have a history of bleeding disorders, and intravenous heparin has been considered for bridging warfarin. Considering his medication history and lab findings, which of the following would generally not be a contraindication to performing central neuraxial anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Recent use of aspirin

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presents to the pain clinic for a procedure involving local anesthetic infiltration for pain management. The physician wants to ensure that the patient receives adequate anesthesia with minimal systemic absorption issues. What is the correct order of routes for the absorption of local anesthetics from fastest to slowest?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Intercostal, Brachial, Epidural, Caudal

choices.text: Effective even if wrong gas is filled in cylinder

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement regarding pin index system?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Pin is present on machine

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of GERD is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist chooses a supraglottic airway device specifically designed to allow concurrent placement of a gastric tube for suctioning and decompression. Which airway device is most likely being used in this scenario?

A medical student studying the materials used in anesthesia is examining the components of soda lime, a CO2 absorbent utilized during surgeries to remove carbon dioxide from breathing circuits. Given the typical composition of soda lime provided in the list below, which of the following compounds is not included in its composition?

choices.text: Increased cardiac output due to sympathetic stimulation
Blockade of parasympathetic nerve fibers leading to increased heart rate
Blockade of sympathetic nerve fibers causing vasodilation in the lower extremities
Direct negative inotropic effect of the anesthetic on the myocardium

questions.text: During a cesarean section under spinal anesthesia, a patient experiences a significant drop in blood pressure and tachycardia. Which of the following is the primary mechanism causing this?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Blockade of sympathetic nerve fibers causing vasodilation in the lower extremities

choices.text: Age-related decrease in minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
Hepatic metabolism of sevoflurane is impaired in elderly
Increased MAC requirement due to chronic alcohol use
Intraoperative awareness causing paradoxical BIS drop

questions.text: A 74-year-old alcoholic undergoing hip replacement under general anesthesia is maintained on sevoflurane. Midway through surgery, his BIS drops to 40 and his BP falls to 70/40 mmHg. His MAC is 1.0. What is the most likely reason for excessive anesthetic depth in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Age-related decrease in minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is in the ICU on mechanical ventilation due to refractory seizures. He is on continuous IV infusion for sedation. On day 3, he develops metabolic acidosis, elevated CK, hyperkalemia, and ECG shows peaked T waves. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Combined spinal-epidural anesthesia with slow titration

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with known hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is scheduled for transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) due to long-standing lower urinary tract symptoms. He has a resting left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) gradient of 45 mmHg and echocardiographic evidence of asymmetric septal hypertrophy. He is currently on beta-blockers and diuretics. Which of the following is the most preferred anesthetic technique for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) General anesthesia with controlled ventilation

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is undergoing elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist is reviewing the MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) values of various inhalational agents to determine the appropriate dosing. Match the following inhalational agents with their corresponding MAC values in adults breathing 100% oxygen at sea level:

 

Agents:

 

  1. Halothane
  2. Isoflurane
  3. Sevoflurane
  4. Desflurane

 

MAC Values:
 

  1. 1.4%
  2. 0.75%
  3. 6.0%
  4. 2.0%

choices.text: Radial nerve block at the spiral groove

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the operating room for excision of a superficial soft tissue mass on the dorsum of his hand. The anesthesiologist plans to perform a peripheral nerve block for intraoperative anesthesia. The ultrasound image below was obtained during the procedure. Which nerve block is most consistent with this ultrasound image?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Axillary brachial plexus block

questions.text: Match the following oxygen delivery devices with their approximate maximum inspired oxygen concentrations (FiO₂) delivered under standard conditions:

A 70-year-old man is undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. He is administered a drug that is known to undergo metabolism via a temperature- and pH-dependent process that does not require enzymatic activity. This unique property allows the drug's breakdown to remain consistent even in patients with impaired liver or renal function. Which of the following best describes this metabolic pathway?

A 35-year-old woman is scheduled for laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy under general anesthesia. During her pre-anesthesia evaluation, the anesthesiologist asks her to open her mouth and protrude her tongue as shown in the image. Based on this finding, which Mallampati class does she most likely have, and what is the anticipated ease of intubation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Class II –likely to be easy

questions.text: A 58-year-old man collapses in the emergency department waiting area. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated after confirming pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the monitor. After the first shock and administration of first dose of amiodarone, defibrillation is repeated. The rhythm remains refractory. According to current ACLS guidelines, what is the correct second dose of amiodarone to administer?

A patient who was being given intercostal nerve block for rib fracture suddenly collapsed while the block was being performed. He is diagnosed to have local anesthetic systemic toxicity. What is the treatment of this condition?

A 72-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with severe left-sided chest pain and difficulty breathing after a fall from standing height. Chest X-ray reveals multiple non-displaced rib fractures from the 4th to the 7th ribs on the left side. The pain limits his ability to cough and deep breathe, putting him at risk for pneumonia. He is started on oxygen and IV fluids. In addition to IV analgesia, which regional anesthesia technique would provide the most effective pain control and improve pulmonary mechanics in this patient?

choices.text: It is a redundant circuit not used anymore

questions.text: This circuit is used in:

A senior cardiologist discusses a congenital heart defect with residents, focusing on a developmental anomaly due to anterior displacement of the cono-truncal septum, which causes an unequal division of the conus cordis. Which condition is associated with this defect?

choices.text: It terminates directly into the axillary vein
In the arm, the cephalic vein lies along the lateral side of the biceps brachii
In the Deltopectoral Groove, it is accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery
The cephalic vein lies in the roof of the anatomical snuff box

questions.text: A patient is set for total hip replacement surgery, and as part of the preoperative preparation, a venous line is inserted in the anatomical snuff box on the left wrist. Evaluate the following statements regarding this venous access point and identify the incorrect one:
questions.solution: Ans. C) In the Deltopectoral Groove, it is accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals facial dysmorphism with a small jaw, low-set ears, and a notched philtrum. Further investigations reveal hypocalcemia and decreased T-lymphocyte count. Genetic testing confirms a 22q11.2 microdeletion. A chest X-ray shows an absence of the organ as shown in following histological image. Identify the organ:

During a medical seminar focused on abdominal anatomy, a question arises concerning the innervation of the skin near the umbilicus. A surgeon asks the attendees to identify which nerve provides sensory innervation to this specific area. Which nerve supplies the skin around the umbilicus?

During an anatomy demonstration involving a cadaver, the instructor challenges the students to identify the vascular structure positioned midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. Which structure is located at this midpoint?

A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty and pain while trying to move her hand sideways. Upon examination, it is determined that the issue is related to the abduction of the hand. Which muscle is primarily responsible for the abduction of the hand?

A 45-year-old male construction worker presents with difficulty in flexing his fingers and an inability to grasp objects properly. On examination, his hand is as shown in the image. Which of the following muscles are most likely paralyzed in this patient?

choices.text: Infraorbital nerve in the inferior orbital fissure
Nasopalatine nerve in the incisive foramen
Auricular branch of the vagus nerve in the tympanomastoid fissure
Vidian nerve in the pterygoid canal

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of chronic nasal congestion and excessive rhinorrhea that have persisted for years despite medical therapy, including antihistamines and intranasal steroids. The patient has no history of allergies, sinus infections, or structural abnormalities in the nasal cavity. The ENT specialist recommends a surgical procedure that involves transecting a nerve passing through a canal in the sphenoid bone. Which of the following nerves is most likely targeted in this procedure?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Vidian nerve in the pterygoid canal

questions.text: In a neuroanatomy class the professor is teaching the projections of different brain structures into thalamic nuclei. The instructor points to a structure labelled by an arrow in the image and asks about its thalamic connections. Which thalamic nucleus does the structure indicated by the arrow project into?
Match the correct pair:

choices.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.
There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side
The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand is weak

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?
questions.solution: Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

questions.text: A 62-year-old right-handed male presents to the neurology clinic with difficulty speaking following a stroke. His speech is slow, labored, and non-fluent, but he appears to understand spoken language well. He often becomes frustrated when trying to express himself. Which area of the cerebrum is affected in this patient?

A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of fatigue, dizziness, and syncope, especially during physical activity. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and a systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram reveals severe aortic stenosis. Right coronary artery origin part was affected. Where does the right coronary artery originate from?
Which of the following speech disorder is caused by the injury of the structure shown in the given slide?
Which of the following is not a derivative of the neural crest cells?

A 45-year-old patient comes to the clinic with complaints of difficulty in moving his foot outward and a lack of sensation over the lateral aspect of his leg and the top of his foot. He reports that the symptoms began gradually after he started a new exercise routine that involves running. On physical examination, there is weakness on foot eversion and decreased sensation on the dorsum of the foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?

A 50-year-old woman presents with unilateral facial paralysis, including the inability to close her eye and drooping of the corner of her mouth on the left side. Which of the following muscles is not paralyzed in the clinical condition shown in the image?

A 25-year-old male presents with difficulty flexing his elbow. Physical examination reveals weakness in the muscles that flex the forearm. Involved muscle is making the floor of the red triangle in the image provided. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?

A 30-year-old surgeon is reviewing anatomy in preparation for a hernia repair surgery. He is focusing on the inguinal region, specifically the boundaries of Hesselbach's triangle, which is crucial for understanding inguinal hernias. Which of the following structures forms the lateral boundary of Hesselbach's triangle?

choices.text: Failure in closure defect of anterior neuropore at 4 weeks intrauterine life
Failure in closure defect of posterior neuropore at 6 weeks intrauterine life
Failure in closure defect of posterior neuropore at 4 weeks intrauterine life
Failure in closure defect of anterior neuropore at 6 weeks intrauterine life

questions.text: A newborn presents with a congenital defect characterized by an exposed mass in the cranial region, as shown in the picture. This presentation is indicative of a failure in the closure of one of the neuropores during intrauterine life. Which developmental defect is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Failure in closure defect of anterior neuropore at 4 weeks intrauterine life

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with foot pain following a recent injury. An X-ray of the right foot is performed, showing the anatomy pertinent to his symptoms. Which bone is indicated by the arrow in the provided X-ray image?

choices.text: Lower border of the upper rib
Upper border of the lower rib
Lower border of the lower rib

questions.text: A medical intern is being taught the correct technique for performing a pleural tap (thoracentesis). The supervising physician emphasizes the importance of needle placement to avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerves. At which anatomical landmark should the needle ideally be inserted for this procedure?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Upper border of the lower rib

choices.text: a-ii , b-iii , c- iv, d- i
a-ii , b-i , c- iv, d- iii
a-iii , b-ii , c- iv, d- i
a-i , b-ii, c- iv, d- iii

questions.text: “Where your ‘ANATOMY’ ends there my ‘CBI ANATOMY’ starts” – you are able to speak this dialogue if you are able to match the following column correctly:
questions.solution: Ans. D) a-i , b-ii, c- iv, d- iii

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes an upper GI endoscopy for evaluation of dysphagia. During the procedure, the endoscope encounters a normal narrowing in the middle portion of the esophagus. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this normal esophageal narrowing?
Which type of joint is shown in image?

A health policy advisor is tasked with drafting guidelines for a new national program aiming to provide universal health coverage and eliminate out-of-pocket health expenditures. In the process, he consults previous committee recommendations on this topic. Which committee’s framework would be most relevant for his reference?

choices.text: Each DMC covers a fixed population of 1 lakh in both plains and tribal areas
One TB Unit supervises up to 10 DMCs
DMCs are operated by microbiologists employed by ICMR
DMCs are the most peripheral unit in the NTEP hierarchy, staffed by a trained lab technician

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Designated Microscopy Centres (DMCs) under NTEP?
questions.solution: Ans. D) DMCs are the most peripheral unit in the NTEP hierarchy, staffed by a trained lab technician

questions.text:
A public health resident is reviewing compliance with the Factories Act at a manufacturing unit employing adolescents. Which of the following statements are true regarding provisions for adolescent workers under the Act?

 

  1. Children aged 14–18 can work in any industry if their parents consent.
  2. Working hours must not exceed 4.5 hours per day for adolescents.
  3. Adolescents are permitted to work between 6 AM and 7 PM only.
  4. Adolescents can be engaged in continuous night shifts if medically fit.

A 24-year-old woman in her second trimester presents for antenatal counseling. She is advised dietary changes to meet her increased micronutrient demands. Which of the following nutrient RDAs is correctly matched for her current physiologic state?
Match the statistical test with the correct scenario:

choices.text: Discard the paper towels in the general waste
Wipe the area with 70% isopropyl alcohol only
Clean the surface immediately with 10% hypochlorite
Saturate the area immediately with 0.5% sodium hypochlorite

questions.text: During a phlebotomy mishap, 100 mL of blood spills onto the countertop. You don nonsterile gloves, pick up any broken glass with tongs, and absorb the spill with paper towels. What is the next correct step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Clean the surface immediately with 10% hypochlorite

questions.text: A bioterrorism response team is prioritizing pathogens for early detection and surveillance. Which of the following agents would fall under Category B, warranting enhanced diagnostics but not likely to cause mass panic or high mortality?

A country introduces a public health policy offering financial incentives and access to advanced reproductive technology only to couples with documented high IQ and no familial genetic disorders. This approach best exemplifies which of the following?

choices.text: RR = 6; Positive association between smoking and lung cancer

questions.text: A cohort study finds that the incidence of lung cancer among smokers is 30 per 1000 person-years, while among non-smokers it is 5 per 1000 person-years. What is the relative risk, and how should it be interpreted?
questions.solution: Ans. A) RR = 6; Positive association between smoking and lung cancer

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding fertility and mortality indicators?

 

  1. Crude birth rate (CBR) uses mid-year total population in the denominator.
  2. Total fertility rate (TFR) accounts for all women in childbearing age based on current age-specific fertility rates.
  3. Infant mortality rate (IMR) uses live births in the denominator.
  4. Net reproduction rate (NRR) considers survival of daughters through childbearing age.

choices.text: Yellow bag – incineration or plasma pyrolysis

questions.text: A hospital generates human anatomical waste during a surgical procedure. According to standard biomedical waste management rules, which container should be used for collection and what is the correct disposal method?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Yellow bag – incineration or plasma pyrolysis

choices.text: Early referral to NICU in all cases
High delivery attendance by unskilled personnel
Excessive focus on postnatal care over prenatal services

questions.text: A rural maternal health program in India shows high antenatal registration but persistent high IMR. Which of the following is most likely to explain this paradox?
questions.solution: Ans. C) High delivery attendance by unskilled personnel

questions.text: In a randomized controlled trial evaluating a new antihypertensive drug, the null hypothesis states that the drug has no effect on blood pressure. After analysis, the investigators find a p-value of 0.02 and reject the null hypothesis, even though the drug is actually ineffective. What type of statistical error has occurred?

choices.text: High PPV due to high sensitivity
High PPV due to high specificity
Low PPV due to low disease prevalence
PPV remains constant across all prevalence rates

questions.text: A new rapid antigen test for typhoid has a sensitivity of 98% and specificity of 95%. In a region with a very low prevalence of typhoid, which of the following best describes the expected trend in its positive predictive value (PPV)?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Low PPV due to low disease prevalence

questions.text: If the basic reproductive number (R₀) of measles in a population is 15, what minimum percentage of the population must be immunized to achieve herd immunity threshold (HIT)?

choices.text: Administer both vaccines simultaneously at different sites
Administer yellow fever now and cholera vaccine after 3 weeks
Postpone yellow fever vaccine and prioritize cholera
Administer cholera vaccine orally and delay yellow fever by 1 week

questions.text: A 35-year-old traveler is scheduled to receive the yellow fever vaccine before flying to sub-Saharan Africa. On the same day, he is also offered oral cholera vaccine. What is the most appropriate recommendation?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Administer yellow fever now and cholera vaccine after 3 weeks

questions.text: A middle-aged mill worker presents with severe burning pain in his feet, purple discoloration of toes, and dry gangrene. He recalls eating a large share of “home-milled rye” bread. What vasoactive compound is most responsible for his presentation?

Indicate True (T) or False (F) for each statement about observational designs:

 

  1. A field trial is categorized under experimental studies.
  2. Case–control studies can directly calculate relative risks.
  3. Community trials allocate interventions at the group level.
  4. Cross-sectional studies are ideal for measuring disease incidence.
questions.solution: Ans. A) T, F, T, F

choices.text: Operational efficiency is adequate, but transmission remains high
Case detection is insufficient—ABER should be lowered
Slide Positivity Rate (SPR) must exceed API for elimination
Elimination achieved, switch to serological surveys

questions.text: A district malaria officer notes that, despite high Annual Blood Examination Rates (ABER), the Annual Parasitic Incidence (API) remains unchanged at 5 per 1,000. Which operational conclusion is most justified?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Operational efficiency is adequate, but transmission remains high

questions.text: In a hypothetical cohort of 10,000, age is a confounder between alcohol use and stroke. After layering by age into two equal groups, the risk differences for alcohol use are identical across groups, indicating no residual confounding. This suggests successful control by ______.

A 24-year-old laboratory technician accidentally punctures her glove while handling a typhoid patient’s blood. Two days later she feels well but—knowing her exposure risk—has her stools cultured. Although asymptomatic, she is shedding Salmonella typhi continuously, even after appropriate antibiotic therapy, for well over one year. What type of carrier is she?

A healthy 72-year-old man with no prior varicella history presents for routine care. He has never received herpes zoster vaccine, pneumococcal vaccines, or traveled outside the U.S. Which of the following immunizations is strongly recommended for him at this visit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine

 

The varicella vaccine is recommended for children and adolescents, the zoster vaccine is specifically recommended for adults 50 and older, with the recombinant zoster vaccine being the preferred option. But if elderly is sure of having never suffered from CPox in childhood or ever taking the varicella vaccine, then yes in such a situation its better to go for Varicella vaccine first

questions.text: A busy tertiary hospital is chronically understaffed on night shifts, leading to delayed medication administration and errors. Leadership decides to create clear, measurable performance goals for each nursing team and ties bonus pay to meeting them. Which management method is being used?
Match each instrument with the most appropriate hospital application:

A 55-year-old farmer presents with high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a history of handling sick prairie dogs on his ranch. On exam, he has several red papules on his ankles consistent with flea bites like those shown. Which organism is most likely responsible for his illness?
